G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, this Court has the authority to modify a custody order when the moving party demonstrates a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the last custody judgment and that modification is in the best interests of the children.

Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.raw_text: Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct. 239, 245 (2015)
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, this Court has the authority to modify a custody order when the moving party demonstrates a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the last custody judgment and that modification is in the best interests of the children.
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses standards for initial custody determinations and removal, and mentions best interests of the child repeatedly, but it does not address the standard or authority for *modifying* an existing custody order. There is no language about a required showing of a ‘material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the last custody judgment’ as a prerequisite to modification. Therefore, this case does not provide authority for the specific Massachusetts modification standard stated in the proposition.
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “In Massachusetts the focus in a custody dispute between parents is not on their personal rights but on the welfare of the child… ‘[i]n deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare.’ … In exercising discretion, the judge is authorized ‘to consider the widest range of permissible evidence.’” (88 Mass. App. Ct. at 245-246)

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: The best interests of the children remain the paramount consideration in all custody matters in Massachusetts.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that in removal and custody-related determinations, “the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern,” and then explains how those interests must guide the analysis. Although the context is a removal case following a custody award, the court is clearly articulating a general principle applicable to custody matters in Massachusetts. Thus the citation accurately supports the proposition that the children’s best interests are paramount in custody matters.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “As most recently reformulated by the Supreme Court of New Jersey in Cooper v. Cooper, 99 N.J. 42 (1984), the ‘real advantage’ test is grounded on the ‘realization that after a divorce a child’s subsequent relationship with both parents can never be the same as before the divorce . . . [and] that the child’s quality of life and style of life are provided by the custodial parent.’ Id. at 53. Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern, ‘[b]ecause the best interests of a child are so interwoven with the well-being of the custodial parent…’”}

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840 (200.proposition: The best interests of the children remain the paramount consideration in all custody matters in Massachusetts.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840 (200.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly discusses the best-interests standard as the guiding principle in Massachusetts custody cases and cites prior precedent stating that “the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern.” The court reaffirms that custody under G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a) is determined “as may be appropriate in the best interests of the child,” and treats that standard as controlling in all custody determinations. This directly supports the proposition that the children’s best interests are the paramount consideration in Massachusetts custody matters.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840 (200.relevant_excerpt: “Section 10 (a) gives a probate judge the power to award custody of nonmarital children ‘to the mother or the father or to them jointly ... as may be appropriate in the best interests of the child.’ … It has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649, 657 (2002) …; Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985) (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’).”

E.N.O. v. L.M.M., 429 Mass. 824, 828 (19.proposition: A custodial parent’s ability to foster a positive relationship between the children and the other parent is a critical factor in determining the best interests of the children.
E.N.O. v. L.M.M., 429 Mass. 824, 828 (19.support_reasoning: The case focuses on whether a de facto parent is entitled to visitation based on the child’s best interests and the Probate Court’s equity jurisdiction. While it repeatedly emphasizes that the child’s best interests are paramount and balances those interests against the legal parent’s custodial rights, it does not identify or discuss a custodial parent’s ability to foster a positive relationship with the other parent as a distinct or critical best-interests factor. The opinion is centered on recognizing and protecting the child’s relationship with a de facto parent, not on evaluating a legal custodian’s willingness to support that relationship as a key determinant in custody or visitation decisions.
E.N.O. v. L.M.M., 429 Mass. 824, 828 (19.relevant_excerpt: “We must balance the defendant’s interest in protecting her custody of her child with the child’s interest in maintaining her relationship with the child’s de facto parent.… What tips the scale is the child’s best interests. ‘The first and paramount duty of courts is to consult the welfare of the child.’ … The child’s interest in maintaining his filial ties with the plaintiff counters the defendant’s custodial interest.”

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257, 259–60 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: A custodial parent’s ability to foster a positive relationship between the children and the other parent is a critical factor in determining the best interests of the children.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The opinion thoroughly discusses best-interest factors in removal and custody modification, including the child’s relationships with both parents and extended family, but it does not single out the custodial parent’s ability to foster a positive relationship with the other parent as a “critical” or decisive factor. The court notes that both parents have fostered family relationships and that the mother would continue to foster contact, yet this is one consideration among many and not elevated doctrinally as a key factor. Thus, the case does not clearly establish the specific principle stated in the proposition.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “Caleb’s close relationship and frequent contact with his extended family predates the divorce. That he remains close to his grandparents and other family members since the divorce reflects a concerted effort on the part of both parents to foster and maintain familial relationships that had existed during the marriage.… In any case, the evidence is clear that the mother has continued, even after the change in custody, to assure Caleb’s ongoing contact with extended family members, that she is close to her family, and would continue to foster contact with them and with members of the father’s family.”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 404 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.proposition: Disparagement of one parent by the other has been held to undermine the children’s emotional stability and can warrant a custody modification.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss one parent disparaging the other, the effect of such disparagement on children’s emotional stability, or custody modification based on that conduct. Its custody analysis focuses on joint versus sole custody, the parents’ inability to cooperate, and which parent is the primary nurturing caretaker. There is no language tying disparagement to emotional harm or using such behavior as a ground for changing custody, so the case does not support the specific proposition claimed.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.relevant_excerpt: “The judge concluded that ‘joint custody or shared responsibility is an invitation to continued warfare and conflict.’ … The judge found the wife has been the ‘primary nurturing parent’ and ‘primary caretaker’ and that the children have the ‘strongest bond’ with their mother. These factors are highly significant for the welfare of the children, and are thus critical considerations for the judge in deciding on a custodial arrangement which minimizes disruption and fosters a healthy environment for the growth and development of the children.”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 185 (20.proposition: Courts may also consider the emotional well-being of the children when evaluating a request for modification of custody.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 185 (20.support_reasoning: The case discusses the ‘best interests of the children’ standard in the context of a removal/relocation dispute where parents share joint physical and legal custody. While the court’s analysis naturally encompasses the children’s overall welfare (including educational, social, and some emotional aspects), the opinion does not specifically address or articulate a rule about considering children’s emotional well‑being in the context of a ‘request for modification of custody.’ Its holding is framed in terms of removal under G.L. c. 208, § 30, not a general custody-modification standard focused on emotional well-being.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 185 (20.relevant_excerpt: “‘The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.’ … ‘[T]he best interests of the child standard is one grounded in the particular needs and circumstances of the individual child in question.’ … Where physical custody is shared, the ‘best interest’ calculus pertaining to removal is appreciably different from those situations that involve sole physical custody.”

Bak v. Bak, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608, 622 (.raw_text: Bak v. Bak, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608, 622 (1987)
Bak v. Bak, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608, 622 (.proposition: Courts may also consider the emotional well-being of the children when evaluating a request for modification of custody.
Bak v. Bak, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608, 622 (.support_reasoning: The opinion is a direct appeal from an initial divorce and custody judgment, not a request to modify an existing custody order. The court discusses the ‘best interests of the children’ standard and various factors (school, community ties, sibling relationships, cultural opportunities), but nowhere addresses standards for modifying custody or a motion to modify. Thus, it does not provide authority on what courts may consider when evaluating a request for modification of custody, even though it does consider the children’s overall well-being in an original custody determination.
Bak v. Bak, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608, 622 (.relevant_excerpt: “Finally, Anthony maintains that the grant of custody of Rosemary and Tony to Sonja was wrong. A Probate Court judge must settle custody in a manner that advances the best interests of the children… The judge could give consideration to the report of one of the court’s family service officers that Tony had not suffered any emotional damage as a result of his forced removal from Germany… Many of the reasons why Rosemary’s interests are better served by staying with her mother apply equally to Tony.”

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: Massachusetts courts seek to ensure that parenting schedules promote stability and minimize unnecessary conflicts between parents.

Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237, 2.raw_text: Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237, 243 (2000)
Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237, 2.proposition: Massachusetts courts seek to ensure that parenting schedules promote stability and minimize unnecessary conflicts between parents.
Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237, 2.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on deciding which parent should have custody based on the best interests of the child, including the parents’ ability to communicate and make joint decisions. While the court notes that joint custody is inappropriate where there is continuous conflict and that judges must consider parents’ ability to communicate, it does not articulate a general principle that parenting schedules should be structured to promote stability and minimize unnecessary conflict. Any inference about minimizing conflict is indirect and tied to the statutory prerequisites for joint custody, not to parenting schedules broadly.
Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237, 2.relevant_excerpt: “Joint custody was not feasible in the circumstances presented here. As we have stated (see note 8, supra), G. L. c. 209C, § 10(a), provides that a judge may award the parents joint custody of a child where the parents have entered into an agreement or the court finds that they have successfully exercised joint responsibility for the child and have the ability to communicate and plan with each other concerning the child’s best interests. … [W]here the judge … [has] found that the relationship of the parties has been dysfunctional, virtually nonexistent, and one of continuous conflict, he properly [may] determine[] that custody should be awarded only to one parent.”

Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488, 495 (2012.proposition: Massachusetts courts seek to ensure that parenting schedules promote stability and minimize unnecessary conflicts between parents.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488, 495 (2012.support_reasoning: The court explicitly discusses that, in determining custody under the best-interests standard, judges should consider factors such as stability of the child’s living arrangements, the parent’s work schedule, and whether a parent seeks to undermine the child’s relationship with the other parent. It upholds a custody arrangement and parenting schedule that prioritize the more stable home, continuity of care, and a parent who will support the child’s relationship with the other parent, thereby minimizing conflict. This directly aligns with the proposition that Massachusetts courts aim for stability and reduced parental conflict in parenting schedules.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488, 495 (2012.relevant_excerpt: “Factors a judge may weigh are whether one parent’s home is more stable in terms of a parent’s work schedule, whether siblings are being raised together, and whether one parent seeks to undermine the relationship a child has with the other parent. See … Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237, 244 (2000) (custody to parent willing to respect other parent’s role in child’s life)… The judge found that disrupting the attachment a child has to a parent and behaving in ways designed to alienate a child from that parent causes harm that can be long term…”
